data.name: paragraph
data.body: Note, in particular, that both \( v \) and \( i \) reach zero, minimum, and maximum values at the same time. Clearly, the voltage and current are in phase with each other.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: We see that, like the applied voltage, the current varies sinusoidally and has corresponding positive and negative values during each cycle. Thus, the sum of the instantaneous current values over one complete cycle is zero, and the average current is zero. The fact that the average current is zero, however, does not mean that the average power consumed is zero and that there is no dissipation of electrical energy. As you know, Joule heating is given by \( i^2R \) and depends on \( i^2 \) (which is always positive whether \( i \) is positive or negative) and not on \( i \). Thus, there is Joule heating and dissipation of electrical energy when an AC current passes through a resistor.

data.body: To express AC power in the same form as DC power (\( P = I^2R \)), a special value of current is defined and used. It is called root mean square (rms) or effective current and is denoted by \( I_{\text{rms}} \) or \( I \).

data.body: Above equation gives the relation between ac current and ac voltage and is similar to that in the dc case. This shows the advantage of introducing the concept of rms values. In terms of rms values, the equation for power and relation between current and voltage in ac circuits are essentially the same as those for the dc case.It is customary to measure and specify rms values for AC quantities. For example, the household line voltage of 220 V is an rms value with a peak voltage of \( V_m = \sqrt{2} \times V = (1.414) \times (220 \, \text{V}) = 311 \, \text{V} \).

data.name: paragraph
data.body: In fact, the rms current (\( I_{\text{rms}} \)) is the equivalent DC current that would produce the same average power loss as the alternating current. The equation for power can also be written as \( P = \frac{V^2}{R} = IV \) (since \( V = IR \)).
